message.content: We refer to reliable sources on dental emergencies for help. Submerging the tooth in milk is the best method to transport it as it helps to preserve the periodontal ligament cells that are essential for successful reimplantation. Normal saline and water can damage the cells, and wrapping in gauze can cause further damage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The best method to transport the tooth is to submerge it in milk, which will help preserve the viability of the periodontal ligament cells in the root surface of the tooth. Normal saline or water may damage the roots of the tooth, and wrapping in gauze soaked in normal saline may cause drying of the root surface.

We refer to the American Dental Association's guidelines for help. The best method to transport a tooth that has been knocked out is to submerge it in milk or the patient's own saliva to keep it moist and preserve the cells, increasing the chances of successful reimplantation. Normal saline or water are not recommended as they can damage the tooth's cells, and wrapping it in gauze can cause further damage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Submerging the tooth in milk is the best method to transport it as it helps to preserve the viability of periodontal ligament cells, which are critical for successful reimplantation. Normal saline or water can also be used if milk is not available, but they are not as effective as milk. Wrapping the tooth in gauze soaked in normal saline may further damage the tooth and its periodontal ligament.

We refer to the American Dental Association's website for help. The best method to transport the tooth is by submerging it in milk. Milk contains proteins and sugars that help preserve the cells of the tooth. Normal saline and water are not ideal because they lack these nutrients. Wrapping the tooth in gauze soaked in normal saline can also cause damage to the tooth's surface.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The best method to transport a knocked-out tooth is to immediately place it in a container of cold milk to prevent it from drying out and to provide a suitable environment for transportation. Normal saline or water can also be used if milk is not available, and the tooth should not be wrapped in gauze as it may damage the root surface.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The best method to transport a tooth is to place it in milk to help preserve the cells and prevent dehydration. Normal saline can also be used in place of milk, but water and gauze soaked in normal saline are not recommended. It is important to transport the tooth to the emergency department as soon as possible, ideally within 30 minutes, for the best chance of successful reimplantation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The best method to transport the tooth is to submerge it in milk, as this helps preserve the viability of the periodontal ligament cells. Normal saline or water can also be used, but milk is the preferred option. Wrapping the tooth in gauze and soaking it in normal saline can cause the ligament to dry out and reduce the chance of successful replantation.

We refer to American Dental Association guidelines for help. Of the options, the best method to transport a knocked-out tooth is to keep it submerged in milk or the patient's own saliva to prevent it from drying out. Normal saline or water can also be used, but milk or saliva is the ideal choice. The tooth should not be wrapped in gauze, as this can cause further damage to the root surface. It is important to transport the tooth to the dentist or emergency department as soon as possible for the best chance of successful reimplantation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Milk is the most ideal medium for transporting avulsed teeth as it preserves the periodontal ligament cells, which are necessary for successful replantation. Normal saline and water can also be used, but milk is the optimal choice. Wrapping the tooth in gauze soaked in normal saline is not recommended as it can damage the periodontal ligament cells.
